Objections || The Self-Refutation Objection
6.7 The Self-Refutation Objection

The PJP holds that all coercive actions or laws require justification
for each member of the public. But critics ask whether this treatment
applies to the PJP itself. If so, then given that reasonable people
disagree about the PJP, the PJP is self-refuting. But suppose the PJP
needs no public justification; if so, its defenders make an arbitrary
exception for their moral principle. (Wall 2002; Christiano 2010,
206–213; Estlund 2008; Wall 2013; Enoch 2013,
170–173).

Some respond by arguing that their version of the PJP can satisfy
itself (Estlund 2008). Other public reason liberals exclude the PJP
from public justification, but they then argue that the exclusion is
not arbitrary. (Gaus 2011; Vallier 2016a; Bajaj 2017. This objection
applies to any interpretation of the PJP. For a more recent
discussion, see Billingham 2017b.)
